metadata.title: A Formal Theory of Commonsense Psychology: How People Think People Think
metadata.authors: Andrew S. Gordon and Jerry R. Hobbs
metadata.description: Chapter 41 axioms covering decision-making processes, choice sets, deliberation methods, justifications, and consequences including choice enumeration, selection, and evaluation
metadata.notation: First-order logic with reified decision processes, choice evaluation, and temporal process control

axioms.title: Definition of decision
axioms.fol: (forall (e0 a s e) (iff (decision e0 a s e) (exists (e1 e2 e3) (and (choiceEnumeration e1 a s)(deliberation e2 a s) (selection e3 a e s)(member e s) (before e1 e3)(before e2 e3)(subevent e1 e0) (subevent e2 e0)(subevent e3 e0)))))
axioms.english: Decision-making process follows three steps: 1. Identify choices ('think of the possibilities') 2. Deliberate about choices ('think about the possibilities') 3. Select one choice ('settle on'). Restaurant example: look at menu to identify choices, think about them, then select one. Choice enumeration e1 and deliberation e2 must occur before selection e3, but e1 and e2 can be interleaved.

axioms.title: Definition of choiceEnumeration
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 a s) (iff (choiceEnumeration e1 a s) (exists (e5 e) (and (changeTo' e1 e4)(thinkAbout' e4 a s) (believe a e5)(decideTo' e5 a e)(member e s) (before e4 e5)))))
axioms.english: Choice enumeration is the process of identifying a set of options. It's a change to a situation where agent is thinking about the set of options, and agent believes he will decide on some member e of s after thinking about s. Coming to think of options or have them in focus, recognizing that one must be chosen.

axioms.title: Definition of deliberation
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 a s) (iff (deliberation e2 a s) (exists (p g e) (and (plan p a g)(selection g a e s) (forall (e4) (if (member e4 s) (exists (e5) (and (thinkAbout' e5 a e4) (subgoalIn e5 p)))))))))
axioms.english: Deliberation is thinking about the options with the goal of selecting one. There is a plan p whose top-level goal is to select an option and thinking about each option constitutes a subgoal in the plan. The thinking is in service of the selection.

axioms.title: Definition of selection
axioms.fol: (forall (e3 a e s) (iff (selection e3 a e s) (and (decideTo' e3 a e)(member e s) (exists (e2) (and (deliberation e2 a s)(before e2 e3))))))
axioms.english: Selection is the third part of making a decision - to select one option from the choice set, after deliberating. The act by agent a to select option e from set s amounts to deciding to do e after deliberating about the set s of options.

axioms.title: Selection preference implication
axioms.fol: (forall (e e3 e4 a s) (if (and (selection e a e3 s)(member e3 s)(member e4 s) (nequal e3 e4)(etc)) (preferGoal a e3 e4)))
axioms.english: If one eventuality e3 is selected and another e4 is not, then we should expect the agent a to prefer e3 over e4 as goals to achieve (or actions to perform). This is a defeasible rule with (etc) condition.

axioms.title: Definition of decisionRevision
axioms.fol: (forall (e a e3 e4 s) (iff (decisionRevision e a e3 e4 s) (exists (e1 e2) (and (decision e1 a s e3)(decision e2 a s e4) (change' e e1 e2)))))
axioms.english: A person may change his or her mind after making a decision ('renege on,' 'go back on'). A decision revision is a decision to choose an alternative once a decision has already been made. A change from decision e1 selecting e3 to decision e2 selecting e4.

axioms.title: Definition of suspendDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e0 e1) (iff (suspendDecision e0 e1) (exists (a s e e3 t) (and (decision e1 a s e)(suspend' e0 a e1 t) (selection e3 a e s)(subevent e3 e1) (before t e3)))))
axioms.english: People can suspend a decision before they make a selection ('sleep on it'). The suspend action e0 applied to decision-making process e1 takes place before the selection subevent e3 of e1.

axioms.title: Definition of resumeDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e0 e1) (iff (resumeDecision e0 e1) (exists (a s e e2 t) (and (decision e1 a s e)(resume' e0 a e1 t) (suspendDecision e2 e1)(before e2 t)))))
axioms.english: People can resume decision-making processes that they earlier suspended ('finish deciding'). The resume action e0 applied to decision-making process e1, where there was a suspend-decision action e2 before the resumption.

axioms.title: Definition of linkedDecisions
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 e2) (iff (linkedDecisions e1 e2) (exists (a s1 s2 e3 e4) (and (decision e1 a s1 e3)(decision e2 a s2 e4) (causallyInvolved e3 e2)))))
axioms.english: Some sets of decisions are interrelated, in that the options chosen have a causal influence on the other decisions. Decision processes e1 and e2 are causally linked when the choice e3 from decision e1 is causally involved in decision process e2.

axioms.title: Definition of decisionSeries
axioms.fol: (forall (s) (iff (decisionSeries s e1) (exists (e2) (or (and (linkedDecisions e1 e2)(doubleton s e1 e2)) (exists (s1) (and (linkedDecisions e1 e2) (decisionSeries s1 e2) (addElt s e1 s1)))))))
axioms.english: Linked decisions can constitute a series of decisions. A pair of linked decisions is a decision series. Adding a decision at the beginning of a decision series results in a decision series.

axioms.title: Definition of choiceSet
axioms.fol: (forall (s e) (iff (choiceSet s e) (exists (a e1) (decision e a s e1))))
axioms.english: For any decision there are a number of possible choices ('range of candidates'). This is the third argument of the predicate decision - the set s of alternatives considered.

axioms.title: Definition of possibleChoice
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 s) (iff (possibleChoice e1 s) (exists (e) (and (choiceSet s e)(member e1 s)))))
axioms.english: Any member in the choice set is a possible choice ('option,' 'prospect,' 'alternative'). An element e1 of choice set s for some decision process e.

axioms.title: betterChoice constraint definition
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 e2 s a e) (if (betterChoice e1 e2 s a e) (exists (e3) (and (decision e a s e3)(possibleChoice e1 e) (possibleChoice e2 e)))))
axioms.english: Constraints on the arguments of the predicate betterChoice. For e1 to be a better choice than e2, both must be possible choices in some decision process e by agent a with choice set s. The actual choice e3 may or may not equal e1 or e2.

axioms.title: betterChoice utility constraint
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 e2 s a e e3 g1 g2) (if (and (decision e a s e3) (possibleChoice e1 e)(cause e1 g1)(goal g1 a) (possibleChoice e2 e)(nequal e1 e2) (forall (g2) (if (and (cause e2 g2)(goal g2 a)) (moreImportant g1 g2 a)))) (betterChoice e1 e2 s a e)))
axioms.english: A weak constraint capturing something like utility: that choice that leads to achieving a more important goal is a better choice. If e1 causes goal g1 and e2 causes goals that are all less important than g1, then e1 is a better choice than e2.

axioms.title: Definition of choiceCharacteristic
axioms.fol: (forall (e0 e1 e a) (iff (choiceCharacteristic e0 e1 e a) (exists (s e3) (and (decision e a s e3)(possibleChoice e1 e) (arg* e1 e0)(goalRelevant e0 a)))))
axioms.english: Each possible choice has different characteristics relevant to the decision ('distinguishing features,' 'pros and cons'). These are properties of the possible choices that are relevant to the agent's goals. e0 is goal-relevant to agent a and involves choice e1.

axioms.title: Definition of bestChoice
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 s a e) (iff (bestChoice e1 s a e) (forall (e2) (if (possibleChoice e2 e) (or (equal e1 e2) (betterChoice e1 e2 s a e))))))
axioms.english: After deliberation, one may be able to identify the best choice ('frontrunner,' 'cream of the crop,' 'leading candidate'). Choice e1 is best if for every other possible choice e2, either e1 equals e2 or e1 is a better choice than e2.

axioms.title: Definition of selectedChoice
axioms.fol: (forall (e3 e a) (iff (selectedChoice e3 e a) (exists (s) (decision e a s e3))))
axioms.english: After selecting, one of the possible choices becomes the selected choice ('one's pick,' 'one's decision'). Choice e3 is selected in decision process e by agent a.

axioms.title: Definition of unselectedChoice
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e a) (iff (unselectedChoice e2 e a) (exists (s e3) (and (decision e a s e3)(nequal e2 e3)))))
axioms.english: After selecting, all but one of the possible choices become unselected choices ('not make the cut,' 'decided against'). Choice e2 is unselected when it's not equal to the selected choice e3 in decision e by agent a.

axioms.title: Definition of previouslySelectedChoice
axioms.fol: (forall (e3 e1 a s) (iff (previouslySelectedChoice e3 e1 a s) (exists (e2 e4) (and (decision e1 a s e3)(decision e2 a s e4) (nequal e3 e4)(before e1 e2)))))
axioms.english: When given the same choice set another time, there is a previously selected choice. Item e3 was chosen by agent a out of set s in decision process e1, when there's also a later decision process e2 by agent a selecting a different e4 out of the same set s.

axioms.title: Definition of envisionChoiceConsequences
axioms.fol: (forall (e3 e s1) (iff (envisionChoiceConsequences e3 e s1) (exists (a s e0 e1 e2) (and (decision e a s e1)(and' e2 e0 e1)(cwu e0 a) (envisionFromTo' e3 a e2 s1)))))
axioms.english: One way people come to decisions is by predicting the outcome of a particular choice ('look before you leap'). We add a possible choice to our current world understanding and envision from that to a set of consequences. Process e3 envisions consequences s1 of choice e1 in decision e.

axioms.title: Definition of pro
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e1 e) (iff (pro e2 e1 e) (exists (e3 s1 a s) (and (envisionChoiceConsequences e3 e s1) (decision e a s e1)(member e2 s1) (goodFor e2 a)))))
axioms.english: One way people make decisions is by weighing pros and cons. A pro is an envisioned consequence that is good for the agent. Consequence e2 of choice e1 in decision process e is a pro when it's good for the agent making the decision.

axioms.title: Definition of con
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e1 e) (iff (con e2 e1 e) (exists (e3 s1 a s) (and (envisionChoiceConsequences e3 e s1) (decision e a s e1)(member e2 s1) (badFor e2 a)))))
axioms.english: A con is an envisioned consequence that is bad for the agent. Consequence e2 of choice e1 in decision process e is a con when it's bad for the agent making the decision.

axioms.title: Definition of costBenefitAnalysis
axioms.fol: (forall (e e0 a s) (iff (costBenefitAnalysis e e0 a s) (exists (s1) (and (decision e0 a s e1)(subset s1 s)(not (null s1)) (forall (e3) (iff (member e3 e) (exists (e4 e5 e6) (and (thinkOf' e3 a e4)(member e6 s1) (or (pro' e4 e5 e6 e0) (con' e4 e5 e6 e0))))))))))
axioms.english: A cost-benefit analysis is the agent's considering each alternative in the choice set and determining if it results in a pro or a con. (A cost is a con; a benefit is a pro.) It's a set of envisionChoiceConsequences activities by the agent - a set of thinking-of actions about whether consequences are pros or cons.

axioms.title: Definition of chooseOver
axioms.fol: (forall (a e1 e2) (iff (chooseOver a e1 e2) (exists (e0 s) (and (decision e0 a s e1)(doubleton s e1 e2)))))
axioms.english: An agent can choose one option over another. Agent a chooses option e1 over e2 if and only if there is a decision process e0 in which the choice set consists of e1 and e2 and e1 is the option that is chosen.

axioms.title: Definition of choiceCriterion
axioms.fol: (forall (e p e0) (iff (choiceCriterion e p e0) (exists (a s e1) (and (decision e0 a s e1) (forall (e2 e3) (if (and (member e2 s)(member e3 s) (subst e2 e4 p e)(Rexist e4) (subst e3 e5 p e)(not e5)) (chooseOver a e2 e3)))))))
axioms.english: People have criteria ('yardstick,' 'benchmark,' 'litmus test') by which they determine which possible choice is the best choice. e is choice criterion for options p in decision process e0; if e is true of e2 but not e3, then agent will choose e2 over e3.

axioms.title: Definition of obviousDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e) (iff (obviousDecision e) (exists (a s e1 e0 e3 e4 s1 s2) (and (decision e a s e1)(betterChoice' e0 e3 e4 s a e) (scaleDefinedBy s1 s e0)(Hi s2 s1)(inScale e1 s2) (forall (e2) (if (and (member e2 s)(nequal e2 e1)) (not (inScale e2 s2))))))))
axioms.english: After deliberation, people find that some decisions are obvious ('no brainer,' 'clear cut'). One way to characterize this is that one option is a much better choice than any other. The best choice e1 is in the Hi region of the scale while no other choice is in the Hi region.

axioms.title: Definition of uncertainDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e) (iff (uncertainDecision e) (exists (a s e1) (and (decision e a s e1) (not (exists (e2) (bestChoice e2 s a e)))))))
axioms.english: After deliberation, people may not have any certainty about the best choice. Decision e is uncertain when there is no identifiable best choice among the alternatives.

axioms.title: Definition of insignificantDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e) (iff (insignificantDecision e) (exists (a s e1) (and (decision e a s e1) (forall (e2 e3) (if (and (member e2 s)(member e3 s)) (not (betterChoice e2 e3 s a e))))))))
axioms.english: After deliberation, one may feel that it doesn't matter which choice is made ('inconsequential,' 'immaterial'). No option in the choice set s is a better choice than any other option.

axioms.title: Definition of decisionFactor
axioms.fol: (forall (f e) (iff (decisionFactor f e) (exists (a s e1 e2) (and (decision e a s e1) (or (pro f e1 e) (and (con f e2 e)(member e2 s) (nequal e2 e1)))))))
axioms.english: People have justifications for the choices that they select. A factor in a decision is a pro for the option selected or a con for an option not selected. Factor f in decision e is either a pro for the selected choice or a con for an unselected alternative.

axioms.title: Definition of decisionJustification
axioms.fol: (forall (j e) (iff (decisionJustification j e) (forall (f) (iff (member f j)(decisionFactor f e)))))
axioms.english: A decision justification is the set of decision factors. Because of the definitions of 'pro' and 'con,' it is the causal story built up by envisioning from the options during the course of deliberation. Set j contains exactly the decision factors for decision e.

axioms.title: Definition of arbitraryDecision
axioms.fol: (forall (e) (iff (arbitraryDecision e) (exists (j) (and (decisionJustification j e)(null j)))))
axioms.english: Sometimes people have no justification for the decision they make ('whim,' 'impulsive decision,' 'crap shoot'). Decision e is arbitrary when its decision justification j is null (empty).

axioms.title: Definition of decisionConsequence
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e a) (iff (decisionConsequence e2 e a) (exists (s e1) (and (decision e a s e1)(causallyInvolved e1 e2) (causallyInvolved e e2)))))
axioms.english: There can be decision processes that are not carried to completion. When they are, however, they have consequences. By making a decision, people make things happen in the world. Eventuality e2 is a consequence when both the selected option e1 and the decision process e itself are causally involved in e2.

axioms.title: Definition of positiveDecisionConsequence
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e a) (iff (positiveDecisionConsequence e2 e a) (and (decisionConsequence e2 e a)(goodFor e2 a))))
axioms.english: Sometimes the effects of a decision are in accord with the agent's goals. A positive decision consequence is a decision consequence that is good for the agent.

axioms.title: Definition of negativeDecisionConsequence
axioms.fol: (forall (e2 e a) (iff (negativeDecisionConsequence e2 e a) (and (decisionConsequence e2 e a)(badFor e2 a))))
axioms.english: Sometimes the effects of a decision are counter to people's goals. A negative decision consequence is a decision consequence that is bad for the agent.

conversion_notes.reified_predicates: Extensive use of primed predicates for decision processes and mental activities: changeTo', thinkAbout', decideTo', suspend', resume', change', betterChoice', envisionFromTo', pro', con'
conversion_notes.defeasible_reasoning: One axiom (41.5) uses (etc) condition for defeasible preference implication from selection
conversion_notes.process_control: Comprehensive framework for suspending and resuming decision processes with temporal constraints
conversion_notes.decision_framework: Systematic three-stage process: choice enumeration, deliberation, selection
conversion_notes.cross_references: Integration with planning theory, envisioning theory, process control, and goal preference systems
conversion_notes.consequence_analysis: Formal treatment of decision outcomes including pros/cons, cost-benefit analysis, and justifications
conversion_notes.choice_evaluation: Sophisticated framework for comparing choices through criteria, characteristics, and utility considerations
conversion_notes.complex_quantification: Multiple axioms with complex nested quantification especially in decision definition, cost-benefit analysis, and choice criteria

file_format_notes.logical_structure: Complex nested quantification in core definitions with simpler support axioms
file_format_notes.predicate_consistency: Consistent use of decision terminology with clear semantic distinctions
file_format_notes.defeasibility_markers: Minimal defeasible reasoning - only one axiom uses (etc) condition
file_format_notes.reification_patterns: Strategic reification of decision processes, mental activities, and temporal operations
file_format_notes.decision_framework: Systematic treatment of decision-making from enumeration through consequences
